question.body: Which of the following does not produce a substance with antimicrobial properties?

multiple_choice.choice: All of the above secrete a substance with antimicrobial properties.

response.feedback: Incorrect. Sebum from sebaceous glands does have antimicrobial properties, but it isn't the only secretion that does; look at the function of the other gland secretions, too.

Incorrect. Although bacteria metabolize fat in the apocrine secretions, research shows the secretions also contain chemicals such as lysozyme that can be antimicrobial and limit bacterial growth, but those aren't the only secretions that are antimicrobial; look at the function of the other gland secretions, too.
Incorrect. Salt and chemicals in sweat are antimicrobial, but they aren't the only secretions that are antimicrobial; look at the function of the other gland secretions, too.
Correct. All of these glands produce substances with antimicrobial properties.
